Congratulations to five OH seniors for being named 2021 National Merit Scholarship Semifinalists. The students are Shiraz Hasan, Petar Isailovic, Ishan S. Khare, Danielle Sun, and Mattingly S. Wilson.

They are among 16,000 national Semifinalists announced this week. The nationwide pool represents less than 1 percent of U.S. high school seniors and includes the highest-scoring entrants in each state. Our academically talented seniors now have the opportunity to receive one of 7,600 National Merit Scholarships worth more than $30 million.

“We are extremely proud of these students for obtaining such a notable national honor,” said Ben McMurray, principal of Ottawa Hills Junior/Senior High School. “They are excellent students and role models who have excelled in and out of the classroom.”

Read more: https://www.ohschools.org/News/24418

(Pictured left to right are Mattingly, Danielle, Ishan, Petar, and Shiraz.)

Ottawa Hills Junior/Senior High School was one of only 14 schools this year to earn the Harold C. Shaw Memorial School Award. The award is the highest achievement possible for schools competing at the State Science Day. OH has received the honor for two consecutive years.

This year, 258 schools (and 800 students) participated; the event was conducted virtually because of COVID-19. There were two ways for schools to earn the honor:
* have at least four students receive a “Superior” rating from judges for their science presentation
* have at least four projects with 80 percent of the students receiving a “Superior” rating and no students receiving a “Good” rating.

State Science Day is an event sponsored by The Ohio Academy of Science has sponsored the State Science Day since 1949.

Please stay tuned for future details and a final plan, which we hope to release the week of July 13-17. I want to thank the 22 members of the district's Coronavirus Response Team for their ongoing contributions.

And thank you for your continued patience and for being great parents.

What happens with you combine the teaching abilities of the Elementary School's Kevin McKee (phys ed) and Cindy Bodziak (art)? You get a heart-pumping Green Bear Hunt!

Here’s how Mr. McKee's idea works:
Using drawing and coloring skills from Mrs. Bodziak’s class, students create a picture (or pictures) of a Green Bear and place it in a window of their home (a stuff bear works fine, too). That way, OH families and students on walks can see the pictures.

Now, the physical education part: Every time you see a Green Bear in a window, do 10 jumping jacks or star jumps or anything! Students also can map their walks and label where they see a Green Bear. Or take a picture and send it to Mr. McKee (kmckee@ohschools.org).

Happy Hunting!

Undeterred by a one-day weather delay, the Ottawa Hills Elementary Art Fair wrapped up its week-long celebration of artistic exploration today. Art from hundreds of students adorned hallways and exhibits inside the new gym. Family-focused breakfasts Wednesday and today paid homage to French artist Georges Seurat (1859-1891) via the theme: "Sunny-Side Up with Seurat!" (K-6 students will be introduced to his life and art - including the presence of umbrellas in his paintings - in coming weeks.)

Thanks to all the volunteers, vendors who contributed food, and to art specialist Cynthia Bodziak for organizing another terrific fair!

The district received a special state award tonight for how well we kept financial records and accounted for public money for the fiscal year ended 2019. "The Auditor of State Award" is given to less than 8 percent of the approximate 5,900 entities across Ohio that spend taxpayer money.

Accepting the award during the Board of Education meeting was district Treasurer Brad Browne; bestowing it was Lori Brodie, the Northwest Regional Liaison for Keith Faber, the Ohio Auditor of State. The audit for Ottawa Hills Local School did not contain any findings for recovery, material citations, material weaknesses, significant deficiencies, Uniform Guidance (Single Audit) findings or questioned costs.

Congratulations to Mr. Browne and the Treasurer's Office team! Keep countin' those pennies!

It was a night of new faces and new leadership for the Ottawa Hills Board of Education. At its annual organizational meeting, the board Wednesday unanimously chose Rob Gnepper as its new president and Maara Fink as its new vice president. Congratulations to them both! The meeting also featured the swearing-in of Lisa Brown, a first-time board member who won election in November. Congratulations, Lisa!

The board also filled a vacancy by appointing past board member Corey Hupp to a two-year term.

In recognition of Ohio School Board Appreciation Month, Superintendent Dr. Adam Fineske honored the members for their service and presented each with a certificate of appreciation.

The Kadens Family Fitness Center, an idea that started as a vision and a challenge by an Ottawa Hills alumnus, became reality yesterday when a ribbon-cutting officially started a new era in student health and wellness. Using golden scissors on green ribbon, speakers and other dignitaries ceremoniously unveiled the 4,000-square-foot facility; about 100 guests attended the event and tour that followed.

The public is invited to tonight's open house from 6-9 p.m. Enter through the facility's main door, which faces east and toward the building's main parking lot. The space becomes a classroom starting Monday (see related story below). The groundbreaking was May 23; the campaign started Oct. 2, 2019, when Pete (’96) and Amy (Robbins) (’99) Kadens announced their leadership gift to the district.

Third graders received a taste of Lebanon, Poland, and South Korea on Wednesday, as parents of their classmates visited to share customs and traditions of their ancestral homes. Nicole Riga showed images and artifacts from Poland; Maria Jun taught the popular South Korean game Yute; and Joy Hajjar demonstrated and led students in performing a Lebanese dance.

The events, capped by a meal of food from each nation, are part of the grade's annual Culture Fair and coincide with a social studies unit they have been studying. Thanks to our parent speakers; the fellow parents who came to watch and learn themselves; and to our 3rd grade teachers Tori Norman, Amy Lavetter, and Emily Atherine.

post_text: What happens when you ask a couple of dozen students to design the ideal learning space? Ottawa Hills is about to find out. Our students’ ideas for such a place were shared on paper and in online surveys today as part of the district’s ongoing efforts to envision a “learning commons” at the Junior/Senior High School. The workshop in the high school library included lunch for about 30 students in grades 8-10. Superintendent Dr. Adam Fineske organized and led the event. Student teams were given sheets of paper on which they brought to life their ideas; those sheets will be shared with The Collaborative, the architectural firm working with the Board of Education on developing the “learning commons” concept.

OH fifth graders saluted 80 veterans this afternoon with song and poetry and heartfelt gratitude for their service. The event began with a welcome banner outside the building, moved inside where students in the other classes waved mini-flags along a parade route, and ended with an hour-long program in the new gym.

It was a red, white, and blue afternoon at the Elementary School!

Thank you to this year's keynote speaker: Eric Buetikofer, an Army veteran who serves as director of Military and Veteran Affairs at the University of Toledo.
